yes, Anoop, that is a great approach. 
But I feel my simple change will make it more friendly. THe newly added msg are same as the header info, so will not display as the header. And by default, it will help user to quickly get more information, like count. 
So I still feel this is a worthy change.

ChunkSize should be restricted to 64 or 128 MB (the hdfs block size ) max for the data to be moved to/from java layer without OOM condition in java. Hence int should be ok.
Since there are changes to the lob globals and the init interfaces and getting rid of worker threads, we need to ensure that hive tests also pass with use_lib_hdfs OFF and ON.

Earlier LOB threads and LOB processing was done whenever there was hive read. Now it is changed to create LOB threads and LOB processing only when USE_LIBHDFS is set to 'ON' irrespective how the lob globals are initialized via LOB access or HDFS scan.
Thank you Selva for so many valuable  review, I need to better understanding the Java exception handling, I will make that change in the next phase of this work.

I think there is a conceptual issue with this fix and with the original JIRA. The datatype of the dynamic parameter is fixed by the compiler at compile time, so it cannot depend on an expression supplied at run time. There are mechanisms at the CLI level that allow run time manipulation; it may be that ODBC/JDBC allow access to those. (Trafci does not.) But those are limited to changing the datatype only; they do not involve lexical analysis or parsing of the expression. Indeed, given a string 'ABCD' in an EXECUTE USING statement, trafci automatically converts from the character set of the SQL statement to the character set of the column, making the N'xxxx' and _iso88591'xxxx' syntaxes unnecessary.
Following up on that remark: Perhaps the best way to resolve this particular JIRA is with a documentation change. We can simply document this behavior in the SQL Reference Manual.

@zellerh That query works fine will NOT count the extra message rows.

>>set schema sch;

--- SQL operation complete.
>>get tables;

Tables in Schema TRAFODION.SCH
==============================

SB_HISTOGRAMS
SB_HISTOGRAM_INTERVALS
SB_PERSISTENT_SAMPLES
T1

=======================
Summary info of get:
Get 4 rows.


--- SQL operation complete.
>>

>>>>select count(*) from (get tables) t(a);
(EXPR)
--------------------

                   4

--- 1 row(s) selected.

when a GET statement is used in a subquery, then parser automatically sets noHeader flag in the get operator. That causes header and footer rows to not be returned. 
It behaves the same as "get tables, no header".

Hi, Anoop, not ALL get command work. As you mentioned, some GET command will invoke GET recursively, in that case, it doesn't work, I still cannot figure out the reason. But you remind me that it is another work() method.
And, yes, the local var is not good
